You're thinking like a permaculture pro! Marigold and zinnia flowers are excellent choices for attracting beneficial insects, including ladybugs and lacewings. Both flowers are known to attract a variety of beneficial insects, and they're easy to grow and maintain.

**Marigold (Calendula officinalis)**

* Attracts: Ladybugs, lacewings, hoverflies, and parasitic wasps
* Why: Marigold's bright orange and yellow flowers produce a strong, pungent scent that repels nematodes and attracts beneficial insects. Its nectar-rich flowers also provide a food source for adult ladybugs and lacewings.
* Tips: Plant marigold around the perimeter of your garden or intersperse it with your vegetables. It's a low-maintenance, drought-tolerant flower that can thrive in poor soil.

**Zinnia (Zinnia spp.)**

* Attracts: Ladybugs, lacewings, hoverflies, and parasitic wasps
* Why: Zinnia's brightly colored flowers (especially the orange, yellow, and white varieties) produce a rich source of nectar and pollen, attracting a variety of beneficial insects. Their strong, upright stems also provide a convenient landing platform for ladybugs and lacewings.
* Tips: Plant zinnia in a location that receives full sun and has well-draining soil. Deadhead the flowers regularly to encourage more blooms and attract more beneficial insects.

When planting marigold and zinnia, keep in mind the following:

* Plant them in a location that receives full sun (at least 6 hours of direct sunlight) and has good air circulation.
* Use a diverse range of flower varieties to attract a broad spectrum of beneficial insects.
* Incorporate these flowers into your garden design to create a beneficial insect-friendly habitat.
* Avoid using pesticides or insecticides, as they can harm or kill the beneficial insects you're trying to attract.
* Be patient, as it may take some time for the beneficial insects to discover and colonize your garden.

By incorporating marigold and zinnia into your garden, you'll be creating a welcoming environment for ladybugs, lacewings, and other beneficial insects. This will help you build a more balanced ecosystem and reduce your reliance on pesticides. Happy gardening!
